p: The SN Cocuy-Güicán is the ancestral land of Muiscas and Laches, forefathers of the indigenous U’wa group [ 33]. Anthropologists have studied the U’wa’s land use and cosmovision [ 67– 70], but a systematic study of their useful flora does not exist. Ethnobotanical research among the U’wa is essential to complete the inventory of useful plants of the SN Cocuy-Güicán. Through comparative analysis between the ethnobotany of farmers and the U’wa, it can become clear to which extent exchange of knowledge on plant use have taken place among these two groups that once lived surrounded by the same natural resources.
